questions.text: Which of the following is a GnRH antagonist ?
questions.solution:
Leuprolide, goserelin and triptorelin are GnRH agonists.

GnRH antagonists

  • Abarelix
  • Cetrorelix
  • Degarelix
  • Ganireix

questions.text: Which of the following is a Janus associated kinase (Jak) inhibitor ?
questions.solution:
Ruxolitinib is a Janus associated kinase (Jak) inhibitor. Selecetively inhibits both Jak1 and Jak2 over Jak3. Indicated in polycythemia vera and myelofibrosis.

Erlotinib, gefitinib and afatinib are EGFR kinase inhibitors (options b, c and d)

questions.text: Incorrect statement regarding pulmonary toxicity associated with bleomycin is

choices.text: Dry cough is a common initial presentation
Risk of pulmonary toxicity is related to total dose
Pulmonary function tests are helpful in detecting early onset of toxicity

questions.solution:
Pulmonary function tests are not of predictive value for detecting early onset of pulmonary toxicity.

Bleomycin associated pulmonary toxicity:

  • Pulmonary toxicity associated with bleomycin begins with a dry cough, fine rales, and diffuse basal infiltrates on X-ray and may progress to life threatening pulmonary fibrosis (option a).
  • Risk of pulmonary toxicity is related to total dose and significantly increases when total dose exceeds 250 mg (option c).
  • Significant improvement in pulmonary function following recovery can occur but fibrosis is usually irreversible (option d).
  • Exact etiology is not known; immune response to epithelial damage can be the cause.
  • No specific treatment available to ameliorate the toxicity and managed by general symptomatic care. Steroids have variable effect, with maximum effectiveness during in the earliest inflammatory stages of the lesion.

questions.text: The first BCR-ABL kinase inhibitor approved for clinical use is
questions.solution: Imatinib, originally called as “sti 571” (signal transduction inhibitor 571) was the first BCR-ABL kinase inhibitor approved for clinical use. Later, clinical resistance to imatinib led to the development of next-generation inhibitors like nilotinib, dasatinib and bosutinib.

questions.text: Natural alkaloid that is indicated as a sialogogue is
questions.solution:
Pilocarpine is a natural alkaloid that has muscarinic receptor partial agonist activity. It is used as sialogogue for the treatment of xerostomia. Muscarine and arecoline are also natural alkaloids with muscarinin but not used clinically (options a and b).

Bethanechol is a carbomyl derivative and is used for its relaxing effects on urinary tract in treating urinary retention (option d).

questions.text: Which of the following is a quaternary amine compound ?
questions.solution: Glycopyrrolate is a quaternary amine lacking central antimuscarinic effects. It usually does not produce central anticholinergic syndrome. Atropine, scopolamine and dicyclomine are tertiary amine compounds (options a, b and c).

questions.text: Which of the following topical beta blocker is a selective beta 1 blocker ?
questions.solution:
Betaxolol is a selective beta -1 blocker. Majority of the receptors in the eye are of beta 2 subtype. Therefore, betaxolol is less efficacious when compared to non-selective beta blockers.

timolol, levobunolol, metipranolol, and carteolol are non-selective beta blockers indicated in glaucoma (options a, b and d).

questions.text: Which of the following beta agonist can be administered once daily ?
questions.solution:
Indacaterol is classified as very long acting beta 2 receptor agonist and can be used once daily. It is indicated in COPD maintenance and not in bronchial asthma.

Salmeterol and formoterol are long acting beta 2 agonist and is usually administered twice daily (options a and b).

Salbutamol is a short acting beta agonist (option c).

Very long acting beta agonists (VLABAs).

  • Indacaterol
  • Olodaterol
  • Vilanterol

questions.text: Which of the following alpha blockers does not block alpha 2 receptor activity ?
questions.solution:
Prazosin is a alpha-1 selective blocker indicated in hypertension and BPH.

Yohimbine is a selective alpha 2 receptor antagonist (option a).

Phenoxybenzamine and phentolamine are non-selective alpha receptor antagonists (options c and d).

questions.text: All phase II biotransformation reactions involve non-micorsomal enzymes except
questions.solution:
Glucuronidation is the only phase II biotransformation reaction that involves microsomal enzymes.

All the other phase II biotransformation reactions involve non-micorsomal enzymes (options a, b and c).

questions.text: You read a  news alert that a promising therapy for Diabetes Mellitus failed in the last leg of clinical trials and could not get marketing approval because of safety issues. The last leg of a clinical trial before marketing approval refers to which phase of a clinical trial?
questions.solution:
Phase III trials are considered as pivotal trials that are necessary for approval of the majority of drugs.

In some drugs related to rare diseases or oncology, phase II studies are considered as pivotal and the drug may be approved on the basis of phase II studies.

questions.text: Which of the following, acts by inhibiting the action of a transporter?
questions.solution:
Probenecid is a uricosuric agent that acts by inhibiting the organic anion transporter (OATP) in renal tubules.

Pilocarpine is a muscarinic agonist (option a).

Acetazolamide inhibits carbonic anhydrase enzyme (option c).

Vigabatrin is a GABA transaminase inhibitor (option d).

questions.text: Antihistamine having significant antiserotinin activity is
questions.solution:
Cyproheptadine has significant antiserotonergic activity along with antihistamine action. It antagonizes 5-HT2A receptors.

It can increase hunger and is sometimes used for this purpose.

questions.text: Synthetic plasma kallikrein inhibitor approved for the treatment of acute attacks of hereditary angioneurotic edema is
questions.solution:
Ecallantide is a synthetic plasma kallikrein inhibitor approved for the treatment of acute attacks of hereditary angioneurotic edema. It is administered subcutaneously.

Icatibant is a selective Bradykinin B2 receptor competitive antagonist that is approved for the treatment of acute attacks of hereditary angioneurotic edema (option a).

Aprotinin is a natural proteinase inhibitor that was tried in reducing the inflammation during cardiopulmonary bypass surgery (option d).

questions.text: Which of the following is not a TNF alpha inhibitor?
questions.solution:
Anakinra is a recombinant, non-glycosylated form of human interleukin 1A. It is approved for use in rheumatoid arthritis and for cryopyrin-associated periodic syndromes (CAPS).

Infliximab, etanercept, and golimumab are TNF alpha inhibitors (options a, b and d). Adalimumab & Certolizumab are other TNF alpha inhibitors

questions.text: Choose the correct pair matching with the diagram

choices.text: A: Thiazides B: Carbonic anhydrase inhibitors
A: Loop diuretics B: Carbonic anhydrase inhibitors

questions.solution:
A is the loop of Henle; loop diuretics act on the thick ascending limb of the loop of Henle. B is proximal convoluted tubule; carbonic anhydrase inhibitors act on this part.

 

 

Related Pearl: Site and mechanism of action of diuretics

Diuretics  Site of action  

Enzyme/receptor/transporter inhibited 
Carbonic anhydrase inhibitors   Proximal tubule   Carbonic anhydrase  
Loop diuretics  Thick ascending loop of Henle  Na+- K+- 2Cl- symporter
Thiazides Distal convoluted tubule  Na+- Cl- symporter
Epithelial sodium channel inhibitors  Late distal tubule and collecting ducts   ENaC 
Aldosterone antagonists  Late distal tubule and collecting ducts  Mineralocorticoid receptors (indirectly ENaC)

questions.text: Phosphenes are associated with the use of
questions.solution:
Ivabradine use is associated with phosphenes; a transient enhanced lightness in restricted areas of the visual field that are explained by effects on retinal HCN channels.

Ivabradine is a blocker of hyperpolarization-activated HCN ion channels involved in the generation of automaticity in SA node. It is used in patients with heart failure and stable angina in whom beta blockers cannot be used.

questions.text: Class 1A antiarrhythmic agents block the following ion channels
questions.solution: Class 1A antiarrhythmic agents block sodium channels with moderate intensity. It also has an additional action of blockade of potassium channels that is responsible for prolonging the action potential duration.

questions.text: Incorrect statement about angiotensin II is

choices.text: Used clinically to increase blood pressure in shock

questions.solution:
Angiotensin II through central action increases ADH secretion and induces thirst (option b).

Angiotensin II causes the release of aldosterone from the adrenal cortex (option d).

Angiotensin II is recently approved (2017-USFDA) for clinical use to increase blood pressure in patients with septic or other distributive shocks (option a).

questions.text: Calcium channel blocker metabolized by plasma esterase is
questions.solution:
Clevidipine is metabolized by plasma esterase.

It has a very short onset and offset of action (plasma half life ~2 minutes). Used for emergency control of hypertension.

questions.text: The route of administration for PCSK-9 inhibitors (alirocumab, evolocumab) is
questions.solution:
The route of administration for both the approved PCSK-9 inhibitors (alirocumab, evolocumab) is subcutaneous.

Clinical note: administration requirements and storage of PCSK-9 inihbitors are barriers in the treatment of hyperlipidemia when compared with the ease of oral dosage forms of other antihyperlipidemic medications.

questions.text: Sugammadex is a reversal agent for
questions.solution:
Sugammadex is a novel reversal agent for rocuronium and vecuronium.

Sugammadex is a modified gamma-cyclodextran that binds rocuronium and vecuronium tightly and decreases the concentration of free plasma levels.

questions.text: Which of the following is indicated for nicotine deaddiction management ?
questions.solution:
Nicotine replacement therapy, varenicline and bupropion are beneficial in nicotine deaddiction.

Nicotine replacement reduces craving and physical withdrawal symptoms during cessation (option a).

Varenicline is an alpha 4 beta 2 receptor partial agonist that is the prinicipal receptor subtype involved in nicotine addiction (option b).

Bupropion is a weak dopamine and norepinephrine reuptake inhibitor that is helpful in nicotine deaddiction (option c).

questions.text: Which of the following is false regarding prilocaine ?

choices.text: It is an amide local anesthetic
Methemoglobinemia occurs due to a metabolite
Vasoconstrictor must be used to limit systemic absorption

questions.solution:
Option D is false.

Prilocaine is an intermediate acting amino amide (option a). It causes little vasodilation and can be used without a vasoconstrictor.

It increases the risk of methemoglobinemia due to conversion of aromatic ring to O-toluidine and the risk is dose dependent (options b and c). This side- effect is unique to Prilocaine among other LAs and restricts its use to anaethetic requirements in Dentistry.

questions.text: Which of the following is false about xenon?

choices.text: Rare gas that cannot be manufactured
Is expensive and available only in limited quantities
It is extremely soluble in blood
Has minimal effect on cardiorespiratory and other systems

questions.solution:
Xenon is extremely insoluble in blood that provides rapid induction and emergence from anesthesia.

Xenon is a rare gas that cannot be manufactured and has to be extracted from atmosphere. Therefore, the availability is limited and is an expensive anesthetic (options a and b).

Xenon has minimal effect on cardiorespiratory and other systems and no long term side effect is seen (option d).

questions.text: GABA transporter inhibitor among the following is
questions.solution:
Tiagabine acts by depressing GABA transporter GAT-1 that is involved in the removal of synaptically released GABA.

Vigabatrin is an inhibitor of GABA transaminase (option a).

Pregabalin and gabapentin are structurally similar to GABA but do not have any effect on GABA transporter or metabolism (options c and d).

questions.text: Which of the following is not a selective estrogen receptor modulator (SERM)?
questions.solution:
Trimaterene is  is a potassium-sparing diuretic.

Clomiphene, raloxifene and toremifene are selective estrogen receptor modulators (SERM) having agonist or antagonist action at different sites (options a, b and d).

questions.text: Phosphodiesterase 5 inhibitors are indicated in erectile dysfunction. Which of these among them also inhibits phosphodieasterase 6?
questions.solution:
Vardenafil and sildenafil can cause inhibition of retinal PDE6. Blurred vision and blue-green tinting of vision can occur because of inhibition of retinal PDE-6.

Tadalafil and avanfil does not inhibit retinal PDE-6 (options a and b).

questions.text: Which of the following statements accurately depicts the effect of ethyl alcohol on CYP2E1?

choices.text: No effect on both acute and chronic consumption

questions.solution:
Chronic consumption of ethyl alcohol results in the induction of CYP2E1 enzymes and results in faster metabolism of drugs that are dependent on CYP2E1.

Acutely, ethyl alcohol can inhibit the action of various metabolizing enzymes including CYP2E1.

questions.text: Which of the following is an atypical antipsychotic?
questions.solution:
Cariprazine is an atypical antipsychotic with partial agonist activity at D2 receptors and 5-HT2A receptors.

Fluphenazine, perphenazine and thioridazine are first-generation typical antipsychotics having D2 receptor antagonism activity (options a,b and d).

questions.text: CYP2D6 polymorphism can alter the analgesic action of
questions.solution:
Codeine is converted to morphine by CYP2D6. CYP2D6 genetic polymorphism can result in huge variation in codeine’s analgesic and euphoric action.

Diclofenac, morphine and acetaminophen are not metabolized by CYP2D6 (options a, b and d).

questions.text: Interference in cortisol synthesis is seen with subhypnotic doses of
questions.solution:
Etomidate at subhypnotic doses inhibits cortisol secretion by selectively inhibiting CYP11B1 activity.

It is used off-label to treat hypercortisolism when rapid control is needed and the patient is not able to take oral medication.

questions.text: The antidiabetic drug that does not act by increasing insulin secretion is?
questions.solution:
Canagliflozin is a SGLT2 inhibitor that inhibits the sodium-glucose cotransporter localted in the proximal portion of the renal tubule.

It blocks glucose transport in the proximal tubule and lower blood glucose by promoting urinary loss.

Glimipiride and repaglinide are insulin secretagogues (options a and c).

Vildagliptin is a DPP-4 inhibitor and indirectly increases insulin secretion by prolonging the action of GLP-1 (option b).

questions.text: Which of the following bisphosphonate use requires close monitoring of renal function ?
questions.solution:
Zoledronate use has been associated with nephrotoxicity and can cause acute renal failure.

Baseline renal function and monitoring of renal function during therapy with zoledronate is recommended.

questions.text: Mecasermin rinfabate is

choices.text: Recombinant human GH with its binding protein
Recombinant human IGF-1 with its binding protein

questions.solution: Mecasermin rinfabate is a recombinant preparation of human IGF-1 with its binding protein IGFBP-3 whereas mecasermin is just a human recombinant IGF-1 preparation.

questions.text: Therapeutic level of lithium (mEq/L) that is indicated for prophylaxis of mania is
questions.solution:
Therapeutic level of lithium that is indicated for prophylaxis of mania is 0.6-1.0mEq/L

Target therapeutic levels for lithium in various conditions

1.0-1.5mEq/L: Acute mania

0.6-1.0mEq/L: Prophylaxis of acute mania

0.6-1.0mEq/L: Bipolar disorder

questions.text: Antibiotic that is specifically approved for diarrhea-predominant IBS is
questions.solution:
Rifaximin is a RNA synthesis inhibitor approved for use in diarrhea-predominant IBS.

Rifabutin and rifampicin are antitubercular agents (options a and b).

questions.text: A patient diagnosed with peptic ulcer disease is being treated with sucralfate. Which of the following adverse effects can be seen in the patient?
questions.solution:
Gastric bezoar can be seen in a patient taking sucralfate. Sucralfate produces a viscous gel that has a ‘sticky nature’. The sticky nature may be responsible for gastric bezoars, particularly in those with gastroparesis.

Sucralfate is composed of a sulfate of sucrose with Al(OH)3. It undergoes cross-linking to produce a viscous polymer that sticks to epithelial cells and ulcers in acidic environments. It inhibits hydrolysis of the mucosal proteins by pepsin.

It is used in the prophylaxis of stress ulcers, and in conditions where mucosal ulceration is not responding to acid suppression.

Adverse effects of sucralfate include constipation and bezoar formation. It may inhibit absorption of other drugs like digoxin, cimetidine, ketoconazole, and fluoroquinolone antibiotics due to the viscous layer formed in the stomach. Hence it should be taken at least 2 hours after administration if these drugs.

The other options:

Vitamin B12 deficiency and increased risk of bone fractures are side effects of proton pump inhibitors (PPIs). However, their clinical significance has not been proven yet. Hypergastrinemia is more commonly seen with PPIs than H2 receptor antagonists.

questions.text: Incorrect statement regarding beta 2 receptor agonists use in asthma is

choices.text: Muscle tremors are the most common adverse effect
Inhalational agents have lower risk of adverse effects than oral/intravenous agents
Increases free fatty acid levels is seen commonly
Tachycardia is due to both direct and reflex action

questions.solution:
Increase in free fatty acid levels is seen after administration of large systemic doses and not inhalational administration.

Metabolic effects like an increase in free fatty acid levels, insulin, glucose, pyruvate, and lactate are usually seen only after large systemic doses.

Muscle tremors are the most common adverse effect. (Option A)

Inhalational agents have a lower risk of adverse effects than oral/intravenous agents. (Option B)

Tachycardia is due to both direct action on beta 1 and 2 receptors on cardiac tissue and reflex stimulation after peripheral vasodilation. (Option D)

questions.text: Antitussive that is having local anesthetic action is
questions.solution:
Benzonatate is a local anesthetic and acts peripherally by anesthetizing the stretch receptors in the respiratory passages, lungs and pleura. Codeine is an opioid analgesic having specific antitussive action (option a).

Dextromethorphan is a centrally active NMDA receptor antagonist that may be effective as an antitussive (option b).

questions.text: Which of the following is not a parenteral anticoagulant?
questions.solution:
Dabigatran is an oral direct thrombin inhibitor.

Heparin, fondaparinux and enoxaparin (LMWH) are parenteral anticoauglants (options a, b and c).

questions.text: Which of the following is a parenteral antiplatelet agent ?
questions.solution:
Cangrelor is a parenteral reversible inhibitor of P2Y12 receptors. It is administered as intravenous bolus in patients undergoing percutaneous coronary intervention.

Clopidogrel, prasugrel and ticagrelor are oral P2Y12 inhibitors (options a, b and d).

questions.text: Which of the following interleukin preparations are used in severe thrombocytopenia
questions.solution: Interleukin-11 stimulates hematopoiesis and a recombinant human preparation, oprelvekin is indicated in severe thrombocytopenia.

questions.text: Pegloticase is a pegylated form of the following enzyme:
questions.solution:
Pegloticase is a pegylated form of the enzyme urate oxidase (uricase).

It catalyzes the enzymatic oxidation of uric acid into allantoin which is a more water-soluble and inactive metabolite.

It is indicated in severe, treatment-refractory gout or when other urate-lowering agents are contraindicated.

questions.text: Raltegravir belongs to the following class
questions.solution:
Raltegravir is an integrase inhibitor that inhibits HIV 1 viral integrase enzyme and prevents proviral DNA integration into host cells.

Integrase inhibitors

  • Raltegravir
  • Dolutegravir
  • Elvitegravir

questions.text: Incorrect statement regarding “gray baby syndrome” associated with chloramphenicol is

choices.text: Recovery is associated with significant disability
Developmental deficiency of glucuronyl transferase is a causative factor

questions.solution:
In Gray baby syndrome, if recovery happens, usually there are no sequelae.

Gray baby syndrome:

  • Premature neonates are more susceptible (option a)
  • Initial symptoms: vomiting, refusal to suck, irregularly rapid respiration, periods of cyanosis
  • After 1-2 days, the child becomes flaccid and hypothermic and turn an ashen-gray color
  • Death occurs in 40% of patients within 2 days of initial symptoms (option b)
  • Developmental deficiency of glucuronyl transferase activity in neonates and their inability to excrete unconjugated drug adequately through renal excretion are implicated in pathogenesis (option d)

questions.text: Drug of choice for trichomoniasis is
questions.solution:
Metronidazole 2g single dose is the drug of choice. If it fails to treat, it can be repeated in 4-6 weeks.

Tinidazole is more expensive, has a longer half-life than metronidazole, causes fewer gastrointestinal symptoms, and may be useful in treating trichomoniasis that fails to respond to metronidazole. (option B)

Albendazole and mebendazole are anthelmintics and are not indicated for trichomoniasis (options c and d).

questions.text: Which of the following is available for intravenous administration for influenza B infections?
questions.solution:
Peramivir is available for intravenous administration in uncomplicated influenza B infections.

Route of administration of neuraminidase inhibitors in influenza

Zanamivir: Inhalational

Oseltamivir: Oral

Peramivir: Intravenous

Note:

Oseltamavir and Zanamavir IV formulations are only investigational at present

questions.text: Bacteriostatic drug among the following first line antitubercular drugs is
questions.solution:
Bactericidal antituberculosis agents (RIPS)

R: Rifampicin (R)

I: Isoniazid (H)

P: Pyrazinamide (Z)

S: Streptomycin (S)

Ethambutol (E) is the only bacteriostatic agent.

questions.text: Fungal protein synthesis inhibitors among the following is
questions.solution:
Tavaborole inhibits fungal leucyl-tRNA synthetase, thereby inhibiting fungal protein synthesis and finally resulting in fungal cell death.

Terbinafine, nystatin and miconazole disrupts fungal ergosterol function/synthesis (options a, b and d).
